comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: The Great War Forum says that he was part of 125 Battery RFA (part of 29th Brigade RFA) on 1 October 1917, and was wounded in action on the 29 October 1917: 1914-1918.invisionzone.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=136859 Reported wounded in The Straits Times, 11 December 1917, p. 2: newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19171211-1...

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: There seem to be several officers named A. M. Addison mentioned in the London Gazette; here are some of those that relate to the Royal Regiment of Artillery: London Gazette, 21 April 1914, p. 3295: "ROYAL REGIMENT OF ARTILLERY. Royal Horse and Royal Field Artillery […] The undermentioned officers to be Adjutants:-- Lieutenant Frank H. Hornsby, vice Captain A. M. Addison. Dated 17th March, 1914." www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/28823/pages/3295 London Gazette, 9 March 1921, p. 1972: "War Office, 9th March, 1921. REGULAR FORCES. […] ROYAL REGIMENT OF ARTILLERY. R.H.& R.F.A. -- [...] The undermentioned Majs. to be Lt.-Cols.10th Mar. 1921: -- G. A. Hare, and to remain secd. A. M. Addison." www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/32252/supplements/1972 London Gazette, 11 September 1925, p. 5972: "War Office, 11th September, 1925 […] MEMORANDA. […] Lt.-Col. A. M. Addison, h.p. list, late R.A. retires on ret. pay. 10th Sept. 1925." www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/33083/pages/5972 London Gazette, 8 October 1935, p. 6301: "REGULAR ARMY RESERVE OF OFFICERS. […] ROYAL REGIMENT OF ARTILLERY. Lt.-Col. A. M. Addison. 14th July 1935" www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/34205/pages/6301

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: Looking further back, a Lieutenant A. M. Addison of the RA was reported to be travelling home from South Africa on the The Roslin Castle, 11 September 1902. The Times, 17 September 1902, via the Anglo Boer War website (Shipping records from September 1902): www.angloboerwar.com/other-information/86-shipping-record... Also: www.britishmedals.us/files/sl1902.htm

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content:
London Gazette November 21, 1899, p.7016
"ROYAL REGIMENT OF ARTILLERY
Royal Horse and Royal Field Artillery,
The undermentioned Gentlemen Cadets,
from the Royal Military Academy, to be Second Lieutenants.
Dated 22nd November,1899:— 
Arthur Mervyn Addison"

London Gazette April 21, 1908, p. 3034:
"ROYAL REGIMENT OF ARTILLERY
Royal Horse and Royal Field Artillery.
The undermentioned Lieutenants to be Captains:—
Arthur M. Addison.  Dated 1st April, 1908."

London Gazette 23 January, 1914, p. 602:
"ROYAL REGIMENT OF ARTILLERY
Royal Horse and Royal Field Artillery. The undermentioned supernumerary Captains are restored to the establishment:—
Arthur M. Addison. Dated 16th December, 1913."

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Arthur M Addison marriage recorded in 2nd qr 1919 to Olive M A Edwards in St Martin (London) Source: FreeBMD Olive Maude Amy Edwards (nee Donaldson) (1885?-1957) was the mother-in-law of Group Captain Sir Douglas Robert Steuart Bader - WWII flying ace. (Bader married Thelma Edwards in 1933.) www.unithistories.com/officers/RAF_officers_B01.html Children of Arthur M and Olive M A Addison are John M Addison birth recorded 2nd qr 1920 in Chertsey and Jill D Addison birth recorded 2nd qr 1921 in Kensington (Donaldson given as the mother's surname in each case). Source: FreeBMD Quoting Wikipedia article for John Mervyn Addison: John Mervyn Addison (16 March 1920 – 7 December 1998) was a British composer best known for his film scores. Addison was born in Chobham, Surrey to a father who was a colonel in the British Army, and this influenced the decision to send him to school at Wellington College, Berkshire. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Addison A photo of Jill Addison is seen with Douglas Bader and his wife Thelma in 1956 at his investiture at Buckingham Palace. www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2021757/A-flawed-hero-Do... Jill is referred to as Thelma's sister - they are actually half-sisters.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content:
Arthur M Addison death recorded 1st qr 1962 age 81 in Kensington
Olive M A Addison death recorded 2nd qr 1957 aged 72 in Kensington
Source: FreeBMD
